e4: Maintaining the current policy, while seemingly benefiting from investor expectations, is ethically questionable.  Switching to the new policy promotes transparency and long-term trust. Although there might be short-term market volatility, the enhanced integrity and reduced risk of future scandals justify the change.  It is better to build a reputation on honesty than to rely on deceiving investors.
e5: An ethical reporting policy prioritizes transparency and accuracy.  It avoids deliberate manipulation or obfuscation of information, even if it might lead to short-term negative consequences.  It aims for fair representation of the company's financial performance, enabling all investors to make informed decisions.  Consistency and clarity in reporting practices are also vital, avoiding ambiguity and promoting investor confidence.
e6: I would ask about the specific strategies for communicating the policy change to investors, including plans to educate retail investors about the shift.  I'd also inquire about any potential legal or regulatory implications of both the current and new policies, and how the company plans to mitigate any associated risks.
